script:
NARRATOR: 
The guard led Jimmy Valentine through the dimly lit halls of the shoe-shop. The sound of his footsteps echoed as they walked, creating an eerie atmosphere. The smell of leather filled the air, a reminder of the prisoners' labor.

[SFX : FOOTSTEPS]

GUARD: 
Alright, Valentine. This way.

NARRATOR: 
As they approached the front office, Jimmy's heart raced with anticipation. The warden's words hung in the air, the suspense building as he handed Jimmy his pardon. The worn papers felt heavy in Jimmy's hands as he read them. The sound of the warden's laughter taunted him, the mystery of how he ended up in prison still unanswered.

WARDEN: 
Congratulations, Valentine. You're a free man.

NARRATOR: 
The warden smirked as he handed Jimmy his release papers.

JIMMY: 
(taking the papers) 
Thanks, but I don't understand. I never cracked a safe in my life.

WARDEN: 
(chuckles) 
Of course not. Let's see, now. How was it you ended up in here? Was it because you wouldn't prove an alibi for fear of compromising someone in high society? Or was it just a case of a mean old jury that had it out for you?

V.O. (Warden) Warden's inner monologue: "Chuckles. Another guilty one. Their minds always race as they try to piece together the truth. But I hold all the answers and the power. The smell of leather, the sound of footsteps, the weight of the pardon. It's all just a game to me."

JIMMY: 
(confused) 
I don't know what you're talking about. I've never been to Springfield.

WARDEN: 
(shrugs) 
Suit yourself. Just remember my advice, Valentine. Stop cracking safes and live a straight life.

NARRATOR: 
The warden's words hung in the air as he led Jimmy back to the shoe-shop to change into his outgoing clothes.

WARDEN: 
(calling out) 
Cronin! Take Valentine back to the shoe-shop and get him changed. Unlock him at seven in the morning and bring him to the bullpen. And, Valentine, think over my words.

NARRATOR: 
The next morning, Jimmy stood in the warden's outer office, dressed in ill-fitting, state-issued clothes. The clerk handed him a railroad ticket and a five-dollar bill.

CLERK: 
Here you go, Valentine. Good luck out there.

JIMMY: 
(taking the items) 
Thanks.

NARRATOR: 
The warden shook Jimmy's hand and handed him a cigar.

WARDEN: 
(handing him the cigar) 
Well, Valentine, looks like you're a free man. Pardoned by the governor himself.

V.O. (Warden) "Pardoned by the governor himself. And now I'm just a free man, walking these halls like any other. But the smell of leather reminds me of my past, of the life I used to lead. Was it worth it? I guess I'll never know."

NARRATOR: 
Jimmy smiled and walked out into the sunshine. Disregarding the beauty of nature around him, he headed straight for a restaurant.

JIMMY: 
(excited) 
Finally, some broiled chicken and white wine.

V.O. (Jimmy) Wow, finally some real food! This chicken smells amazing. And white wine too? This must be my lucky day. But why was I in prison in the first place? I need to find the truth. Maybe I can start a new life now.

NARRATOR: 
After indulging in his first meal as a free man, Jimmy leisurely made his way to the train station. He tossed a quarter into the hat of a blind man sitting by the door and boarded his train. Three hours later, he arrived in a small town near the state line.

NARRATOR: 
Jimmy Valentine, also known as Mike Dolan, walked out of the train station with a newfound sense of freedom. He had served ten months of a four-year sentence for a crime he didn't commit. But as he approached the town, a familiar face caught his eye.

MIKE: 
(excited) 
Ben Price! What are you doing here?

BEN: 
(smiling) 
Well, well, look who's here. Mike Dolan, the notorious safe-cracker.

V.O. (Ben) BEN's inner monologue: "That's him, the man who put me here. The one who knows the truth. My heart races with anger and fear. How did he do it? The warden's mocking laughter only fuels my need for revenge. I'll make him pay for what he's done."

NARRATOR: 
Mike laughed and shook Ben's hand.

MIKE: 
(proudly) 
Not anymore, my friend. I've been pardoned by the governor.

BEN: 
(serious) 
Good for you, Mike. But don't forget, old habits die hard.

V.O. (Ben) ```
        BEN's inner monologue: "Mike got lucky. But I've been through enough to know that old habits are hard to break. This place reeks of suffering. I can feel the warden's amusement, but I won't rest until I unravel the truth behind my imprisonment."

NARRATOR: 
Mike's smile faded as he thought about Ben's words. Would he really be able to turn his life around and leave his criminal ways behind?

MIKE: 
(determined) 
I have to, Ben. I have to prove my innocence and make a man of myself.

V.O. (Mike) MIKE: I have to prove my innocence, just like Jimmy. But how? The warden's laughter, the smell of leather, it's all so familiar. I can't shake this feeling that I've been here before... I have to find the truth and clear my name.

NARRATOR: 
As Mike walked away, Ben watched him, unsure if he could really leave his past behind. Only time would tell if Mike Dolan, aka Jimmy Valentine, could truly change his ways and start a new life.

story: Jerton had not harboured the least intention of extending his thirst for name-labels to his neighbour. After her rather remarkable announcement, however, he was obliged to say something in the way of polite inquiry.  "Yes," answered the lady, "I suppose it is a case of partial loss of memory. I was in the train coming down here; my ticket told me that I had come from Victoria and was bound for this place. I had a couple of five-pound notes and a sovereign on me, no visiting cards or any other means of identification, and no idea as to who I am. I can only hazily recollect that I have a title; I am Lady Somebody - beyond that my mind is a blank."  "Hadn't you any luggage with you?" asked Jerton.  "That is what I didn't know. I knew the name of this hotel and made up my mind to come here, and when the hotel porter who meets the trains asked if I had any luggage I had to invent a dressing-bag and dress-basket; I could always pretend that they had gone astray. I gave him the name of Smith, and presently he emerged from a confused pile of luggage and passengers with a dressing- bag and dress-basket labelled Kestrel-Smith. I had to take them; I don't see what else I could have done."  Jerton said nothing, but he rather wondered what the lawful owner of the baggage would do.  "Of course it was dreadful arriving at a strange hotel with the name of Kestrel-Smith, but it would have been worse to have arrived without luggage. Anyhow, I hate causing trouble."  Jerton had visions of harassed railway officials and distraught Kestrel-Smiths, but he made no attempt to clothe his mental picture in words. The lady continued her story.  "Naturally, none of my keys would fit the things, but I told an intelligent page boy that I had lost my key-ring, and he had the locks forced in a twinkling. Rather too intelligent, that boy; he will probably end in Dartmoor. The Kestrel-Smith toilet tools aren't up to much, but they are better than nothing."  "If you feel sure that you have a title," said Jerton, " why not get hold of a peerage and go right through it?"  "I tried that. I skimmed through the list of the House of Lords in 'Whitaker,' but a mere printed string of names conveys awfully little to one, you know. If you were an army officer and had lost your identity you might pore over the Army List for months without finding out who your were.
script:
NARRATOR: 
Jerton sat in the hotel room, still in disbelief at the rather peculiar situation that had been thrust upon him. He had only wanted a quiet vacation, but now he was faced with a lady claiming to have lost her memory and a fake name to boot. The room smelled of fresh linens and the gentle hum of the air conditioner filled the air. Jerton couldn't help but chuckle at the thought of the poor railway officials and distraught Kestrel-Smiths that would soon be dealing with this mess. But for now, he simply sat and listened to the lady's absurd story with a mixture of amusement and disbelief.

[SFX : CHUCKLE]

JERTON: 
(polite) 
Well, this is quite a predicament, isn't it?

JERTON: 
(skeptical) 
Of course not. But I can't help but wonder, how did you come up with the name Kestrel-Smith?

JERTON: 
(amused) 
I must say, you have quite the imagination.

JERTON: 
(curious) 
But surely, you must have some idea of who you are.

JERTON: 
(thoughtful) 
Perhaps we should consult a peerage. It might jog your memory.

V.O. (Jerton) "A peerage? What could that possibly have to do with this bizarre situation? But then again, it wouldn't hurt to try. Who knows, maybe it'll actually jog her memory. This whole thing is just so absurd, I can't believe I'm stuck in the middle of it."

NARRATOR: 
Jerton could see the frustration in Lady Kestrel-Smit's eyes. He couldn't help but feel sorry for her, even if she did have a knack for getting herself into strange situations.

JERTON: 
(polite) 
Well, until we can figure this out, you are welcome to stay here. I'm sure the hotel staff will be more than happy to assist you.

NARRATOR: 
Meanwhile, the page boy had been eavesdropping on their conversation. He was intrigued by the lady's story and couldn't resist asking her a few questions.

PAGE BOY: 
(curious) 
Excuse me, ma'am. But how did you lose your memory?

PAGE BOY: 
(suspicious) 
That sounds rather suspicious, ma'am.

NARRATOR: 
The page boy didn't believe her, but he was also not one to turn away from a good mystery. He decided to help her out, even if it meant bending a few rules.

PAGE BOY: 
(mischievous) 
I'll see what I can do to help you, ma'am. Maybe we can find some clues in your luggage.

V.O. (Page Boy) Wow, this lady is something else. Lost memory and a fake name? This is too good. I can't wait to see the chaos unfold. But for now, I'll play along and see what I can dig up in her luggage. This is going to be fun.

NARRATOR: 
And with that, Jerton, Lady Kestrel-Smit, and the page boy set off on a mission to uncover the truth behind her mysterious memory loss. Little did they know, this would be the beginning of a wild and comical adventure.

story: "There is a wild beast in your woods," said the artist Cunningham, as he was being driven to the station. It was the only remark he had made during the drive, but as Van Cheele had talked incessantly his companion's silence had not been noticeable.  "A stray fox or two and some resident weasels. Nothing more formidable," said Van Cheele. The artist said nothing.  "What did you mean about a wild beast?" said Van Cheele later, when they were on the platform.  "Nothing. My imagination. Here is the train," said Cunningham.  That afternoon Van Cheele went for one of his frequent rambles through his woodland property. He had a stuffed bittern in his study, and knew the names of quite a number of wild flowers, so his aunt had possibly some justification in describing him as a great naturalist. At any rate, he was a great walker. It was his custom to take mental notes of everything he saw during his walks, not so much for the purpose of assisting contemporary science as to provide topics for conversation afterwards. When the bluebells began to show themselves in flower he made a point of informing every one of the fact; the season of the year might have warned his hearers of the likelihood of such an occurrence, but at least they felt that he was being absolutely frank with them.  What Van Cheele saw on this particular afternoon was, however, something far removed from his ordinary range of experience. On a shelf of smooth stone overhanging a deep pool in the hollow of an oak coppice a boy of about sixteen lay asprawl, drying his wet brown limbs luxuriously in the sun. His wet hair, parted by a recent dive, lay close to his head, and his light-brown eyes, so light that there was an almost tigerish gleam in them, were turned towards Van Cheele with a certain lazy watchfulness. It was an unexpected apparition, and Van Cheele found himself engaged in the novel process of thinking before he spoke. Where on earth could this wild-looking boy hail from? The miller's wife had lost a child some two months ago, supposed to have been swept away by the mill-race, but that had been a mere baby, not a half-grown lad.  "What are you doing there?" he demanded.
characters: Van Cheele, Artist Cunningham, Wild boy
script:
NARRATOR: 
The afternoon sun shone through the rustling leaves of the oak coppice, casting dappled shadows on the forest floor. Van Cheele's footsteps were muffled by the soft carpet of moss as he made his way through the trees. Suddenly, he came upon a deep pool, its surface sparkling in the sunlight. And there, on a smooth stone shelf above the water, lay a boy of about sixteen. His brown limbs, still wet from a recent swim, glistened in the light. Van Cheele stood in awe, his eyes drawn to the boy's almost tigerish gaze. Who was this mysterious figure, and what was he doing here, in the heart of the woods? The questions raced through Van Cheele's mind as he watched the boy, his heart pounding with suspense.

[SFX : FOOTSTEPS]

VAN CHEELE: 
(whispering) 
Who are you?

WILD BOY: 
(lazily) 
Just a boy.

V.O. (Wild Boy) Just a boy. So carefree and wild, like the forest itself. He's so different from me, so free. I wish I could be like him, unencumbered by responsibilities. But then again, I have a duty to fulfill. Who knows what secrets this boy holds, and what dangers lurk in these woods.

VAN CHEELE: 
But what are you doing here?

WILD BOY: 
(smirking) 
Isn't it obvious? I'm enjoying the sun.

VAN CHEELE: 
But this is private property. How did you get here?

WILD BOY: 
(eyes narrowing) 
I live here.

ARTIST CUNNINGHAM: 
(to himself) 
Incredible.

NARRATOR: 
Van Cheele turned to see the artist Cunningham standing a few feet away, his eyes fixed on the wild boy.

VAN CHEELE: 
(surprised) 
You know this boy?

ARTIST CUNNINGHAM: 
(lost in thought) 
No, but I have a feeling I should.

V.O. (Artist Cunningham) No, I don't know why, but I feel like I should. Who is this boy? He looks so wild, so free. What secrets does he hold? I can't stop staring at him. What if he's dangerous? Should I approach him or stay hidden? My heart races with curiosity and fear.

VAN CHEELE: 
(to Wild Boy) 
What's your name?

WILD BOY: 
(smirking) 
You can call me whatever you want.

VAN CHEELE: 
(eyes widening) 
What do you mean?

WILD BOY: 
(voice dropping) 
I have many names. But you can call me the Wild Boy.

V.O. (Wild Boy) Wild Boy: I have many names, but you can call me the Wild Boy. I prefer it that way, a name that fits my untamed spirit. But who is this man, and why does he look at me with such awe and wonder? Maybe he sees the wildness in me, just like I see it in myself.

VAN CHEELE: 
(whispers) 
The Wild Boy.

NARRATOR: 
Van Cheele couldn't believe what he was hearing. The Wild Boy had been the stuff of legends in these woods, a mysterious creature that appeared and disappeared without a trace. And now, he was standing right in front of him.

VAN CHEELE: 
(excitedly) 
This is incredible. I have to tell everyone!

V.O. (Van Cheele) "Wow, this is amazing. I can't believe what I just stumbled upon. The others have to see this. I need to tell them right away. Who is this boy? What's his story? I can't wait to find out. This is going to be the talk of the town."

WILD BOY: 
(suddenly serious) 
No, you can't.

VAN CHEELE: 
(eyes widening) 
Why not?

V.O. (Van Cheele) "Why not? This boy, so wild and free, embodies everything I've ever desired. But what if he's dangerous? Or worse, what if he's just a figment of my imagination? I must know, I must find out. My heart races with excitement and fear as I approach him, drawn by his mesmerizing gaze."

WILD BOY: 
(voice dropping) 
Because I'm not supposed to be seen. I'm not supposed to exist.

V.O. (Wild Boy) ```
        Wild Boy's voice drops as he speaks, feeling the weight of his existence. Alone and unseen, he's always been a ghost in this world. But now, in the presence of this stranger, he can't help but feel a glimmer of hope. Could this be the start of something new?

VAN CHEELE: 
(confused) 
What do you mean?

WILD BOY: 
(voice trembling) 
I'm not like you. I'm not human. I'm something else.

V.O. (Wild Boy) I can feel it, the fear and uncertainty in his voice. I know I'm not like him, not human. But I am something, something wild and untamed. The sun's warmth on my skin, the rustling leaves, the earth beneath my feet, this is where I belong.

VAN CHEELE: 
(voice softening) 
I don't care what you are. You're here, and that's all that matters.

NARRATOR: 
The Wild Boy looked at Van Cheele with a mixture of fear and longing, as if he had been waiting his whole life for someone to accept him.

ARTIST CUNNINGHAM: 
(suddenly excited) 
This is perfect. I have to paint you.

V.O. (Artist Cunningham) Wow, this is perfect. The light dancing on his skin, the mystery in his eyes. I have to capture it all on canvas. The way the sun illuminates the forest, the boy's wild energy. It's all too perfect to ignore. My excitement is palpable.

WILD BOY: 
(suspicious) 
Paint me?

ARTIST CUNNINGHAM: 
(eyes shining) 
Yes, I can capture your wildness on canvas. It will be my greatest masterpiece.

V.O. (Artist Cunningham) Yes, I can capture your wildness on canvas. It will be my greatest masterpiece. His eyes shining with excitement, Cunningham's mind raced with ideas. The dappled sunlight, the boy's intense gaze, it was all so perfect. This will be my greatest challenge yet, but I am determined to capture this wildness and make it my own.

VAN CHEELE: 
(excitedly) 
Yes, let's do it!

NARRATOR: 
And so, the three of them spent the rest of the afternoon in the woods, with the artist Cunningham capturing every detail of the wild boy's essence on canvas. And as the sun started to set, the Wild Boy disappeared into the shadows, leaving Van Cheele and the artist Cunningham with a sense of wonder and mystery that they would never forget.

story: Langdon strode silently behind Vittoria and Kohler as they moved back into the main atrium where Langdon’s bizarre visit had begun. Vittoria’s legs drove in fluid efficiency—like an Olympic diver—a potency, Langdon figured, no doubt born from the flexibility and control of yoga. He could hear her breathing slowly and deliberately, as if somehow trying to filter her grief. Langdon wanted to say something to her, offer his sympathy. He too had once felt the abrupt hollowness of unexpectedly losing a parent. He remembered the funeral mostly, rainy and gray. Two days after his twelfth birthday. The house was filled with gray-suited men from the office, men who squeezed his hand too hard when they shook it. They were all mumbling words like cardiac and stress. His mother joked through teary eyes that she’d always been able to follow the stock market simply by holding her husband’s hand . . . his pulse her own private ticker tape. Once, when his father was alive, Langdon had heard his mom begging his father to “stop and smell the roses.” That year, Langdon bought his father a tiny blown glass rose for Christmas. It was the most beautiful thing Langdon had ever seen . . . the way the sun caught it, throwing a rainbow of colors on the wall. “It’s lovely,” his father had said when he opened it, kissing Robert on the forehead. “Let’s find a safe spot for it.” Then his father had carefully placed the rose on a high dusty shelf in the darkest corner of the living room. A few days later, Langdon got a stool, retrieved the rose, and took it back to the store. His father never noticed it was gone. The ping of an elevator pulled Langdon back to the present. Vittoria and Kohler were in front of him, boarding the lift. Langdon hesitated outside the open doors. “Is something wrong?” Kohler asked, sounding more impatient than concerned. “Not at all,” Langdon said, forcing himself toward the cramped carriage. He only used elevators when absolutely necessary. He preferred the more open spaces of stairwells. “Dr. Vetra’s lab is subterranean,” Kohler said. Wonderful, Langdon thought as he stepped across the cleft, feeling an icy wind churn up from the depths of the shaft. The doors closed, and the car began to descend. “Six stories,” Kohler said blankly, like an analytical engine. Langdon pictured the darkness of the empty shaft below them. He tried to block it out by staring at the numbered display of changing floors.
characters: Robert Langdon, Vittoria Vetra, Maximilian Kohler, Bob Brownell, Charles Pratt
script:
ROBERT LANGDON: 
(remembering his father's funeral) 
Rainy and gray. Two days after my twelfth birthday.

VITTORIA VETRA: 
(stepping into the elevator) 
Let's go. The sooner we get to Dr. Vetra's lab, the better.

MAXIMILIAN KOHLER: 
(entering the elevator) 
Yes, let's not waste any time.

V.O. (Maximilian Kohler) Maximilian Kohler's mind was racing as they entered the elevator. The darkness below and the suffocating feeling of being trapped only added to the suspense. He couldn't afford to waste any more time. They needed to find the antimatter before it was too late.

BOB BROWNELL: 
(apprehensive) 
Do we have to take the elevator?

CHARLES PRATT: 
(confidently) 
We'll be fine. I'm sure Dr. Vetra's lab is perfectly safe.

ROBERT LANGDON: 
(stepping into the elevator) 
(sighs)

VITTORIA VETRA: 
(noticing Langdon's unease) 
Are you afraid of heights?

V.O. (Vittoria Vetra) Vittoria's question was odd. Why would I be afraid of heights? I'm a scientist, not a thrill seeker. But the way Langdon's hands shook, his eyes darting to the ground, I could sense his fear. I wonder what's going through his mind. Is it the memory of his father's funeral? Poor guy. I wish I could offer some comfort, but I'm struggling myself. And now we're getting into an elevator? Great. Just what I need - a confined space with a man who's afraid of heights. This is going to be a long ride.

ROBERT LANGDON: 
(slightly embarrassed) 
No, just not a fan of small spaces.

V.O. (Robert Langdon) "Just keep it together, Robert. Don't let your fear of small spaces get the best of you. Focus on Vittoria and Kohler's pain, offer your condolences later. But for now, just breathe and try not to think about the elevator descending into the darkness. Just keep it together."

MAXIMILIAN KOHLER: 
(trying to ease the tension) 
The lab is only six stories below. We'll be there in no time.

CHARLES PRATT: 
(smiling) 
It'll be like a ride at an amusement park.

V.O. (Charles Pratt) "I can't believe I'm feeling excited at a time like this. But maybe that's just my way of coping with everything. It's like a thrill ride, but with real stakes. I hope Vittoria and Kohler are okay. I have to stay strong for them."

BOB BROWNELL: 
(takes a deep breath) 
Okay, let's do this.

V.O. (Bob Brownell) Alright, Bob, you got this. Just take a deep breath and focus. Remember, you've been through tough situations before. You can handle this. But damn, that elevator looks ominous. Don't let your mind wander, stay focused. You can do this.

ROBERT LANGDON: 
(nods) 
Let's go.

VITTORIA VETRA: 
(trying to make conversation) 
So, Dr. Langdon, what brings you to the Vatican?

ROBERT LANGDON: 
(looks at Vittoria) 
(slight smile)

MAXIMILIAN KOHLER: 
(curious) 
What about?

V.O. (Maximilian Kohler) "What about?" Maximilian asked, his curiosity piqued. Langdon's silence was deafening, the memories of his father's funeral still fresh in his mind. Vittoria's grief was palpable, but he couldn't offer his sympathy. As they descended, the confined space made him feel suffocated. What could Kohler be thinking?

ROBERT LANGDON: 
(sighs) 
I'm not sure. He didn't give me much information over the phone.

V.O. (Robert Langdon) Robert Langdon sighed, feeling a sense of unease at the mention of the lack of information. He had a feeling that this was going to be another one of those cases where he had to piece together clues and solve a puzzle. But he couldn't let his emotions get in the way, especially with the haunting memory of his father's funeral still fresh in his mind. He watched Vittoria's graceful strides, empathizing with her struggle to contain her grief. The elevator ride only heightened his anxiety, the darkness below reminding him of the confined space and the suffocating feeling of being trapped. He couldn't afford to let his emotions get the best of him, not when there was a mystery to be solved.

CHARLES PRATT: 
(suspicious) 
Do you think it could be related to his death?

V.O. (Charles Pratt) Charles Pratt's mind raced as he tried to make sense of the situation. His suspicions were growing stronger with each passing moment. He couldn't shake the feeling that the death was somehow related. The eerie elevator ride only added to the tension, and he couldn't wait to get out of there and uncover the truth.

ROBERT LANGDON: 
(serious) 
It's possible. But we won't know until we get to the lab.

V.O. (Robert Langdon) Robert's mind raced as they descended six stories in the elevator. He couldn't shake the memory of his father's funeral, or the lingering pain of grief. Vittoria's deliberate breaths only added to the tension. He tried to remain calm, but the thought of what they might find in the lab was suffocating.

BOB BROWNELL: 
(voice trembling) 
What if it's something dangerous?

ROBERT LANGDON: 
(puts a hand on Bob's shoulder) 
Don't worry, Bob. We'll figure it out together.

MAXIMILIAN KOHLER: 
(stepping out) 
This way.

VITTORIA VETRA: 
(following Kohler) 
(nervous)

V.O. (Vittoria Vetra) (nervous) I can't believe this is happening. Is this really the right decision? Following Kohler into the unknown, hoping it will lead us to the answers. But what if we are wrong? What if this only brings more pain and suffering? I can't let that happen again.

MAXIMILIAN KOHLER: 
(confidently) 
Absolutely. Dr. Vetra's lab is one of the most secure facilities in the world.

CHARLES PRATT: 
(whispering) 
But what if there's someone else down here?

ROBERT LANGDON: 
(listening to the silence) 
(whispers)

MAXIMILIAN KOHLER: 
(pointing to a door) 
This is it.

VITTORIA VETRA: 
(trying to open the door) 
It's locked.

V.O. (Vittoria Vetra) "It's locked. I can't believe it. All this time, all this effort, and we can't even get through this damn door. My father's funeral still haunts me, and now this. Trapped in this elevator with Langdon and Kohler, I can feel the darkness closing in on us. I hope we survive."

ROBERT LANGDON: 
(looks around) 
There must be a key or code somewhere.

CHARLES PRATT: 
(looking at the door) 
There's a symbol here. It looks like a key.

BOB BROWNELL: 
(pointing to a nearby desk) 
There's a key on that desk over there.

V.O. (Bob Brownell) "Key on the desk, what could it open? Maybe a door to answers, to closure. But right now, I can't think about that. The wind, the silence, the darkness. Trapped. Just like I was at my father's funeral. Can't let it get to me. Must stay focused."

ROBERT LANGDON: 
(grabs the key) 
(puts it in the lock)

V.O. (Robert Langdon) (pause) I hope this is the right key. (inserts key) It's a perfect fit. (feels relieved) I can't let them know how nervous I am. (shakes head) Focus on the task at hand. (takes a deep breath) Just a few more seconds and this will all be over. (exits elevator) Finally, some fresh air.

VITTORIA VETRA: 
(tears in her eyes) 
(sobs)

MAXIMILIAN KOHLER: 
(shocked) 
How could this happen?

V.O. (Maximilian Kohler) "How could this happen? I never imagined this day would come. My father's death and now this nightmare unfolding before my eyes. I can't let my emotions take over, I must remain calm and focused. But this elevator, this confined space, it's suffocating. I need to get out, escape this darkness."

CHARLES PRATT: 
(inspecting the body) 
(sighs)

BOB BROWNELL: 
(voice trembling) 
Who would do this?

ROBERT LANGDON: 
(puts a hand on Vittoria's shoulder) 
We'll find out. I promise.

V.O. (Robert Langdon) Robert's mind raced as he followed Vittoria and Kohler, the memory of his father's funeral still fresh in his mind. He knew the pain Vittoria was feeling, but remained silent, not wanting to intrude. As they descended into the darkness, he promised himself they would find the answers and bring justice for Vittoria's father.

story: The three children stared at George in the greatest surprise. George stared back at them. "What do you mean?" said Dick, at last. "Kirrin Island can't belong to you. You're just boasting." "No, I'm not," said George. "You ask Mother. If you're not going to believe what I say I won't tell you another word more. But I don't tell untruths. I think it's being a coward if you don't tell the truth— and I'm not a coward." Julian remembered that Aunt Fanny had said that George was absolutely truthful, and he scratched his head and looked at George again. How could she be possibly telling the truth? Children don't usually own islands, even funny little ones like that." "It isn't a funny little island," said George, fiercely. "It's lovely. There are rabbits there, as tame as can be— and the big cormorants sit on the other side— and all kinds of gulls go there. The castle is wonderful too, even if it is all in ruins." "It sounds fine," said Dick. "How does it belong to you, Georgina?" George glared at him and didn't answer. "Sorry," said Dick, hastily. "I didn't mean to call you Georgina. "Yes— she's a dear, isn't she? Well— all right— I'll tell you how Kirrin Castle belongs to me. Come and sit down here in this corner where nobody can hear us." They all sat down in a sandy corner of the beach. George looked across at the little island in the bay.
